direction.raw_text: Son, son, son...               Father, father, father... They part, unsatisfied and confused.  HAROLD goes to PENELOPE, his arms outstretched.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wife, wife, wife... PENELOPE struggles to her feet, her face blank.  HAROLD embraces her, finds himself wrestling with a rigid, unresponsive object.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wife, wife, wife... HAROLD lets go, backs away from her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (tearful) Give us time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like hugging a lamp post.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give us time, Harold--to adjust to your being alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were well adjusted to my being dead?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We adjust to what there is to adjust to.  Perhaps Paul, being young, can adjust to joy or grief immediately.  I hope he can.  I will take a little longer.  I'll be as quick as I can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What sort of time period do you have in mind?  Half an hour?  An hour?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.  This is a new disease to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Disease?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This reunion isn't what I imagined it would be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A telegram--a phone call might have helped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seemed the most honest way to begin life together again--natural, unrehearsed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well--enjoy the natural, honest, unrehearsed result--surgical shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You feel that you're behaving as a woman should?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every fuse in my nervous system has been blown. Lion doorbell roars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's that?  Teddy Roosevelt? PAUL answers the door, admits WOODLY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to PAUL) Safe and sound, I see. (to HAROLD) Oh--you came back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know each other?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We met here earlier this evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How neat.  How keen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How was the emergency, Doctor? Profitable, I hope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A policeman delivered the baby in a taxicab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tough luck.  You'll have to split the fee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (puzzled by PENELOPE's mood) Are--are you crying, Penelope?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's crying because she's so happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why I'm crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Woodly? (indicating HAROLD) You know who this is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't get his name.  A friend of your father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He isn't any friend of Father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He isn't?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is my father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eeeeeeeeeeee-yup.  Dr. Woodly--I would like you to meet Harold, my husband.  Harold, this is Dr. Woodly, my fiance. She crosses to the door of the master bedroom, kissing each male lightly as she passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night, dear.  Good night, dear. She stands in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay or go, talk or sulk, laugh or cry--as you wish.  Do whatever seems called for.  My mind is gone. Good night. She exits into bedroom, closes the door firmly, locks it audibly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (dazedly) I feel the same way.  What next?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What next?  You leave promptly, of course.  There is no question as to whose home this is--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: None.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whose son this is, whose wife that is.  A fiance is the most ridiculous appurtenance this household could have at this time.  Good night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (crushed, without any possible comeback) Good night. He exits through the front door.  HAROLD goes at once to PENELOPE's door, tries it, finds it locked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Penelope!  God damn it!  Penelope! He considers kicking down the door, thinks better of this, turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wants to fix up her makeup, no doubt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is Looseleaf Harper alive?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alive and hale.  He's throwing a little surprise party for his own family.  Is your mother often this unstable? (not waiting for an answer, calling again) Penelope!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's a real heavy sleeper sometimes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you go to bed--son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't take my eyes off you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow's another day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what my English literature teacher said about you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't it keep till morning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She said you were legendary.  I wrote a theme about you, and she said, "Your father is a legendary hero out of the Golden Age of Heroes."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's nice.  You thank her for me. Go to bed and get lots of sleep, and then you thank her in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow's Saturday.  Anyway, she's dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Penelope!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was killed in the park two months ago--in the daytime.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Penelope!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was on her way home from a meeting of the African Violet Society, and they got her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sharply) Will you go to bed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stung) Yes sir.  If you can't wake Mom up, I've got double-decker bunks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (stamping his foot) Scat! PAUL exits hastily down the corridor to his room.  HAROLD goes to PENELOPE's door, attempts to woo her through it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Penelope--darling--can you hear me? Wife--you know what kept me alive all these fevered, swampy, nightmare years?  Your heavenly face, Penelope, my wife--shimmering before me, coaxing me up from my knees, begging me to stagger one step closer to home.  Has love ever reached so far?  Has love ever overcome more hardships than mine? (silence) Has love ever asked more manliness of a man, more womanliness of a woman?  Has ever a man done more for a woman's reward? The bedroom door opens, revealing PENELOPE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hollowly, to the world at large) There is no one in here of any earthly use to anyone tonight. Tomorrow is another day. She closes the door and locks it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to audience) End of Act One. Blackout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom!  Mother!  Mom! Toilet flushes.  Lights come up on the living room.  It is morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad's got jungle fever, Mom. What'll I do?  Mom!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a moment of exhaustion) Damn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom? Door to the master bedroom suite opens.  PENELOPE appears in the doorway.  She has decided during an almost sleepless night that she owes it to PAUL and to her own self-respect to explore the possibility of beginning her life with HAROLD anew.  She is terrified of him.  She hopes that if she can keep calm and open, her fears will diminish.  Perhaps she can love him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (attempting to behave mechanically as a good wife should) What are his symptoms?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shivers and sweats and groans.  His teeth chatter.  What'll we do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does he say to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can hardly talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (responding to a last twinge of nausea) Bluh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd better get Dr. Woodly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is an emergency, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (uncertainly) Yeah.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then get him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (thinking she has made a mistake) Okay. He exits through front door, leaves door open.  We hear him knocking on a door in the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Woodly? HAROLD enters, drained but recovering.  He chews on a root. He has slept in the shirt and trousers he wore the night before.  He is barefoot.  PAUL knocks again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dr. Woodly? There is the sound of WOODLY's door opening.  WOODLY and PAUL speak unintelligibly, WOODLY evidently inviting PAUL in for a moment.  WOODLY's door closes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that all about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We thought a doctor might help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your old beau?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We thought it was an emergency.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want that chancre mechanic in here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a very decent man, Harold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shouldn't you lie down?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I'm dead-- (throwing it away) or fucking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul said you were awfully sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was, I was.  It never lasts long. He hears WOODLY's door open, is alert to WOODLY's approach, continues to speak to PENELOPE absently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Indians call it "Zamba- keetya"--the little cloudburst. WOODLY and PAUL enter.  WOODLY is correctly professional and carries a little black bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah!  You're ambulatory!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a brilliant diagnosis!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what I want? (all look at her) I want you both to be friends.  I know you both, respect you both. You should be friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing would please me more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (believing him) Thank God!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pleased but careful) Well now--what seems to be the trouble with the patient today?  A touch of malaria, perhaps?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know malaria.  Malaria isn't caused by the bites of bats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been bitten by bats?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Colonel Harper and I once shared a treetop with a family of bats. There was a flash flood.  There were piranha fish in the water. That's how Colonel Harper lost his little toe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have chills?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chills, fevers, sweats.  You can describe it and name it after yourself: "the Woodly galloping crud." WOODLY enjoys the joke and the blooming friendship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can also describe its cure. I'm eating its cure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was going to ask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pacqualinincheewa root.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you say that again?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pacqualinincheewa root.  Means "cougar fang." Cures anything but a yellow streak down the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never heard of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Congratulations.  By crossing twenty-eight feet of cockroach- infested carpet, you've become the third white man ever to hear of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (fascinated) Are you've seen it work cures?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hundreds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so glad you like each other.  I was so scared, so scared.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (breaking off a piece, offering it) Have some.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.  Thank you very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe in miracles now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wasn't that sweet of me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More and more we find ourselves laying aside false pride and looking into the pharmacopoeias of primitive people.  Curare, ephedrine--we've found some amazing things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have, have we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's an editorial we, of course. I haven't turned up anything personally.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything about you is the editorial we.  Take that away from you, and you'd disappear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harold!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could carve a better man out of a banana!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You and your damned bedside manner and your damned little black bag full of miracles.  You know who filled that bag for you?  Not Alice-sit-by-the-fires like yourself.  Men with guts filled it, by God--men with guts enough to pay the price for miracles--suffering, ingratitude, loneliness, death--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (off balance) Good Lord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can just hear the editorial wee- wee-weeing when Looseleaf and I start flying in pacqualinincheewa root.  I can hear the Alice-sit-by- the-fires now: "We discovered it in the Amazon Rain Forest.  Now we cure you with it.  Now we lower our eyes with becoming modesty as we receive heartfelt thanks." HAROLD suddenly goes to WOODLY, takes his hand and pretends abject gratitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, bless you, Doctor, bless you-- oh healer, oh protector, oh giver of life. WOODLY withdraws his hand, examines it as though it were diseased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He doesn't deserve this!  You don't know him.  It isn't fair!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He thought he could take my place. It is now my privilege to give an unambiguous account of why I don't think he's man enough to do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought she was a widow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were wrong, you quack!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Awful. (approaching WOODLY, but not getting too close) I can't tell you how sorry I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say hello to your mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (fervently) Do say hello to your mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm taking her to the airport a few minutes from now.  She's going to East St. Louis--to visit an aunt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell her to have a nice trip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (moving towards the front door) Thanks. HAROLD laughs.  This stings WOODLY to a cold, peace-loving anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to have to report you to the Department of Health.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quarantine, possibly.  You may be suffering from a loathsome disease which the American people could do without.  Goodbye. He exits instantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now that's what I call fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ghastly, cruel, unnecessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll get so you enjoy twitting weaklings again.  You used to eat it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We were one hell of a pair--and we'll be one again.  What we need is a honeymoon.  Let's start right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A trip, you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had a trip.  We'll honeymoon here. (to PAUL) Go out and play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Play?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your mother and I do not wish to be disturbed for three full hours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hasn't had breakfast yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Buy yourself breakfast. (takes his billfold from his hip pocket, hands PAUL a $100 bill) There we go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hundred dollars!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The smallest thing I've got.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I get dressed first?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make it fast. PAUL exits to his bedroom.  HAROLD turns to PENELOPE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honeymoon!  Honeymoon!  Say it: Honeymoon!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's so--so stark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You used to like it stark!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just--bang--we have a honeymoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (beginning to stalk her cunningly) I'm not going to strike you.  I am going to be as gentle as pie--as lemon meringue pie.  You mustn't run away now.  This is your loving husband approaching.  I'm your husband.  Society approves! PENELOPE wants to run, but doesn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good!  You held your ground. HAROLD is very close now, but not touching her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now--turn around, if you would.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turn around?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (laughing) I'm not about to introduce to you a jungle novelty.  What I have in mind is massage--a perfectly decent massage.  Turn around, turn around. PENELOPE obeys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to touch your shoulders very gently now.  You mustn't scream. (touches her shoulders gently, expertly) So tense, so tense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shouldn't have talked to Norbert that way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're thinking with your brain instead of your body.  That's why you're so tense!  Forget Norbert. Relax.  It's body time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a brain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We all do.  But now it's body time. Relax.  Ideally, the body of a woman should feel like a hot water bottle filled with Devonshire cream. You feel like a paper bag crammed with curtain rods.  Think of your muscles one by one.  Let them go slack.  Relax.  Let the brain go blank.  Relax.  That's the idea-- that's my girl.  Now the small of the back.  Let those knots over those kidneys unsnarl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (entering, dressed to go out and play) Dad--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hanging on to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but knowing the mood has been broken) Couldn't you have vanished quietly out the back door?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hundred dollars for breakfast?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave a tip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (suddenly twisting away, having been nearly hypnotized) I have some change!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ram it up your ass! He realizes at once that his violent side has severely damaged the side of him which is the great seducer. PENELOPE and PAUL are straight as ramrods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do beg your pardon. (sincerely) Those words were illy chosen. There is tension in all of us here. Something you must both understand, however, is that the head of this household is home, and he is Harold Ryan, and people do what he says when he says it.  That's the way this particular clock is constructed. Lion doorbell roars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sometimes even I hate that thing. PAUL goes reeling to the door in terror, admits LOOSELEAF, who has also been sleeping in his clothes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (walking right in) I've been looking at motorcycles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go home!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ever own a motorcycle?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to PENELOPE) You're right!  We'll take a trip. A trip is what we'll take. (to LOOSELEAF) I don't want to talk about motorcycles.  I don't want to talk about tits.  Go home!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Haven't got one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to LOOSELEAF) And you went home unannounced, too?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dunno.  Yeah!  Yeah!  Yeah!  I did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how were things?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's talk about something else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to HAROLD) Alice got married again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She did?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't even find that out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was so much going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She married an accountant named Stanley Kestenbaum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So that's it! "Kestenbaum, Kestenbaum." Everybody was yelling "Kestenbaum, Kestenbaum." I thought it was some foreign language.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Otherwise, how are things?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sure didn't expect her to drop dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dead!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sick) Alice is dead?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no--shit no. (stops short) Excuse me, Penelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For saying "shit." Or is that okay now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shrilly) Who's dead?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother-in-law.  Fire engines, pulmotors, doctors, cops, coroners--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well--I walked up to the front door. I was still alive.  Big surprise. I rang the doorbell, and old Mrs. Wheeler answered.  She had her Goddamn knitting.  I said, "Guess who?" She conked right out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How horrible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah--cripes.  I never did get any sense out of Alice.  She found me holding up the old lady, dead as a mackerel.  It was a bitch.  You know--maybe Mrs. Wheeler was going to die then and there anyway, even if I'd been the paper boy.  Maybe not.  I dunno, boy.  That's civilian life for you.  Who knows what kills anybody?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could have happened to anybody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First Nagasaki--now this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about breakfast, wife?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Breakfast?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (as though to a waitress) Scrambled eggs, kippered herring, fried potatoes--and a whole onion. I want to eat the onion like an apple.  Do you understand? PENELOPE turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And lots of orange juice--oceans of orange juice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Wheeler is dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All right--bring me a side order of Mrs. Wheeler. (regarding LOOSELEAF, resigning himself to being stuck with his company for a little while longer) Oh, hell--sit down, Colonel. Penelope will bring you some chow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is the most heartless statement I ever heard pass between human lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (honestly mystified) Which one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (chokingly) "Bring me a side order of Mrs. Wheeler."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's up in Heaven now.  She didn't hear.  She is experiencing nothing but pure happiness.  There's nothing nicer than that. (suddenly, angrily, slamming a table with his fist) Chow!  Harold Ryan wants chow!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a honeymoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honeymoon temporarily canceled. (catching sight of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: whose physical appearance really offends him) The boy should still go out and exercise.  I have the impression he never gets any exercise.  He simply bloats himself with Fig Newtons and bakes his brains over steam radiators.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then let me see him go out and get some exercise. (explosively) Right now! PAUL goes reeling in terror to the front door, opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to HAROLD, abjectly) What kind of exercise?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat the shit out of someone who hates you. PAUL exits.  HAROLD pounds on a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chow, chow, chow!  God damn it-- nutriment!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're all going to have to go out for breakfast.  The cook quit yesterday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a woman, aren't you? PENELOPE nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we have a cook. PENELOPE hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cook, by God!  Cook!  You're the nigger now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People don't use that word any more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't lecture me on race relations. I don't have a molecule of prejudice.  I've been in battle with every kind of man there is. I've been in bed with every kind of woman there is--from a Laplander to a Tierra del Fuegian. If I'd ever been to the South Pole, there'd be a hell of a lot of penguins who looked like me.  Cook!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You leave me so--so without-- without dignity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People now have dignity when frying eggs?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They don't have to feel like slaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (grandly) Then go now--and fry with dignity-- sunnyside up. PENELOPE attempts to respond to this, but is too enraged. She exits, making a tiny mosquito-like hum.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dunno, boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The educational process.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I guess.  You're lucky you don't have any old people around here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was about to get married again. She locked me out of the bedroom last night. LOOSELEAF starts to laugh.  HAROLD shuts him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's funny about that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (apologetically) You know me, boy. PENELOPE enters from the kitchen with a question on her lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should have torn that door off its hinges.  Should have scrogged her ears off.  Should have broken the bed. (seeing PENELOPE) What do you want? (words fail her) Well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: was wondering--is there anything you shouldn't eat--because of jungle fever?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could eat a raw baby crocodile. (turning to LOOSELEAF crassly) The way to get your wife back is in bed.  Do such a job on her that she'll be lucky if she can crawl around on all fours. (to PENELOPE) We're starving.  Do you mind? PENELOPE exits dumbly, detesting the word "scrog," which she has never heard before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She had two lovers, by the way. LOOSELEAF starts to laugh again, stops the laugh as HAROLD glowers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of them is the doctor, whose weapons are compassion, unselfishness, peacefulness-- maudlin concern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and his love are like a retiarius.  Do you know what a retiarius is?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a kind of gladiator who fights with a knife and a net and doesn't wear anything but a jockstrap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (amazed) How do you know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You told me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When we were up in the tree so long--with the bats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh.  I'd forgotten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fourteen times you told me.  I counted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd get this funny look in your eyes, and I'd say to myself, "Oh, Jesus--he's going to tell me what a retiarius is again."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (acknowledging a flaw in a manly way) Sorry. PENELOPE enters, is about to speak.  HAROLD stops her with a raised finger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me guess--breakfast is served?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not wish to be scrogged--ever. I never heard that word, but when I heard it, I knew it was one thing I never wanted to have happen to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what you're supposed to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is not a coy deception.  I do not want to be scrogged.  I want love.  I want tenderness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know you want.  That's the way God built you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will not be scrogged.  I remember one time I saw you wrench a hook from the throat of a fish with a pair of pliers, and you promised me that the fish couldn't feel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It couldn't!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to have the expert opinion of the fish--along with yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shaking his head) Fish can't feel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I can.  Some injuries, spiritual or physical, can be excruciating to me.  I'm not a silly carhop any more. (an unexpected, minor insight) Maybe you're right about fish. When I was a carhop, I didn't feel much more than a fish would.  But I've been sensitized.  I have ideas now--and solid information.  I know a lot more now--and a lot of it has to do with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sensing danger) Such as?...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The whole concept of heroism--and its sexual roots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me about its sexual roots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's complicated and I don't want to go into it now, because it's bound to sound insulting--even though nobody means for anybody to be insulted.  It's just the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like the truth.  I wouldn't be alive today if I weren't one of the biggest fans truth ever had.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well--part of it is that heroes basically hate home and never stay there very long, and make awful messes while they're there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (blurting) And they have very mixed feelings about women.  They hate them in a way.  One reason they like war so much is that they can capture enemy women and not have to make love to them slowly and gently.  They can scrog them, as you say-- (pause) for revenge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You learned this in some college course?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I learned a lot of things in college.  Actually--it was Norbert who told me that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (darkly) The doctor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what is his most cherished possession?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (not sensing the drift of the conversation) His most cherished possession?  His violin, I guess.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he keeps it in his apartment?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (still at sea) Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And no one's there now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's too bad.  I would rather have him at home--to see what I'm going to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (suddenly catching on, sick with fear) What are you going to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He did his best to destroy my most precious possession, which is the high opinion women have of me.  I'm now going to even that score.  I'm going to break in his door and I'm going to smash his violin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No you're not!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because if you do--I'll leave you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (promptly and emotionlessly) Goodbye. Blackout. SCENE TWO SPOTLIGHT comes up on VON KONIGSWALD and WANDA JUNE, dressed as before.  They have become close friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have this new club up here in Heaven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, we do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We only have two members so far, but it's growing all the time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have enough for a shuffleboard team.  In Heaven, shuffleboard is everything.  Hitler plays shuffleboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Albert Einstein plays shuffleboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mozart plays shuffleboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lewis Carroll, who wrote Alice in Wonderland, plays shuffleboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack the Ripper plays shuffleboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Walt Disney, who gave us Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, plays shuffleboard.  Jesus Christ plays shuffleboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was almost worth the trip--to find out that Jesus Christ in Heaven was just another guy, playing shuffleboard.  I like his sense of humor, though--you know? He's got a blue-and-gold warm-up jacket he wears.  You know what it says on the back? "Pontius Pilate Athletic Club." Most people don't get it.  Most people think there really is a Pontius Pilate Athletic Club.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're going to have jackets, aren't we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You bet! "The Harold Ryan Fan Club." Pink, eh?  With a yellow streak up the back. (both laugh) We got very good tailor shops up here.  They'll make you any kind of uniform, any kind of sweatsuit you want.  Judas Iscariot--he's got this black jacket with a skull and crossbones over the heart.  He walks around all hunched over, and he never looks anybody in the eye, and written on the back of his jacket are the words, "Go take a flying-- WANDA JUNE punches him in the ribs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: leap at the moon." MILDRED, HAROLD's third wife, enters.  She is voluptuous, blowzy, tough--about forty-five.  She has trouble with alcohol.  VON KONIGSWALD is expecting her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aha!  Hello!  You're Mildred, right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard you were looking for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were Harold Ryan's third wife. Right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want to join the Harold Ryan Fan Club?  Wear a pink jacket with a yellow streak up the back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do I have to?  Who's the little girl?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Ryan just borrowed my birthday cake.  I don't really know him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thought you were another wife, maybe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm only ten years old.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's what he wanted--a ten-year- old wife.  He'd come home from a war or a safari, and he'd wind up talking to the little kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Won't you please join our club? Please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Honey--Alcoholics Anonymous takes all the time I've got--and Harold Ryan is an individual I would rather forget.  He drove me to drink.  He drove his first two wives to drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because he was cruel?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (covering WANDA JUNE's little ears) Premature ejaculation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ach soooooooooo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No grown woman is a fan of premature ejaculation.  Harold would come home trumpeting and roaring.  He would the kick the furniture with his boots, spit into corners and the fireplace.  He would make me presents of stuffed fish and helmets with holes in them. He would tell me that he had now earned the reward that only a woman could give him, and he'd tear off my clothes.  He would carry me into the bedroom, telling me to scream and kick my feet.  That was very important to him.  I did it.  I tried to be a good wife.  He told me to imagine a herd of stampeding water buffalo.  I couldn't do that, but I pretended I did.  It was all over--ten seconds after he'd said the word "buffalo." Then he'd zip up his pants, and go outside, and tell true war stories to the little kids.  Any little kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is sad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (blankly) Is it? (pause) I have this theory about why men kill each other and break things.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ja?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never mind.  It's a dumb theory.  I was going to say it was all sexual..but everything is sexual...but alcohol. (making peace sign) Peace.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: .  PAUL, alone in the living room, hammers on his mother's door.  He wears pajamas.
dialogue.name: dialogue
